column10: The beginner/intermediate, intro to R course was a bit intimidating at first, but everyone was friendly and I got a lot out of it! Overall, great first-time conference. Well worth the $5 student fee.
column16: Good value for the fee paid
column20: compact space, easy to get to other talks; lightning talks were great introduction to people in R community; beginner workshop
column21: didn't get  a name tag, hard to network

column16: Good value for the fee paid
column20: The tidyverse workshop, learning the diverse ways other folks use R
column21:
I would love a baseline intro to the vocab- like the difference between R scripts and R Markdowns, how to knit, keyboard shortcuts. etc. 
Also, Github is a mysterious black magic site.
column22: Thank you very much for blowing my mind about how I can more powerfully tell a story by visualizing my data.

column20: The beginner workshop was very helpful. I had barely glanced at RStudio prior to today, panicked at the very beginning, but I felt I had learned some things by the end. Meeting a couple new folks and "networking" is also very enjoyable; there are a lot of good resources around... More stickers! :D
column21: Maybe different scheduling for the concurrent talks... It was a little inconvenient and disruptive to jump between the two rooms repeatedly.
column22: Thanks overall! Good stuff. :)

column21: I was somewhat disappointed in the quality of the talks, especially the keynotes. Vinay seemed to not know the audience very well and Gabriela's talk, while on an important subject, did not have very much substance to it. Some of the talks also seemed geared towards an academic audience, rather than a diverse assortment of R-users. Overall I wish speakers focused more on specific R packages.

Also felt medical-oriented keynote, while good for bioinformaticians, should have been more coding oriented (not a single mention of R in whole talk).

column21: More time for interaction between the participants.  This one feels like was too jammed with talks.  There was not enough time to get to know each other.  Perhaps Portland R residents know each other rather well.  But those who traveled from distant cities might have missed that human interaction factor.

column10: You all did an excellent job! I'm amazed how it all came together with so few organizers, and it was clear that there was a high demand for such a conference in our region. Way to fill that gap!
column16: Good value for the fee paid
column20: Awesome first keynote: great way to frame the time, incredibly salient issue for the community, and really well-presented.
column21: Perhaps breakout lightening sessions: not all were relevant to everyone's interests so it was a long time to listen to all the topics that had been selected. Having them organized as sessions that people could choose between could help alleviate that (although I realize that it can create conflicts where people want to be in two places at the same time).
column22: Job opportunities could be a great addition as employers advertise opportunities and folks get a sense for the opportunities available.

column22: It was unclear how the first keynote related to R/datasci other than "big data, y'all" and it was not very interesting. The speaker was good but the topic (medical reversals) was boring. Given how many ethics breaches there were recently (e.g. OkCupid & Tinder data scraping and releases) it would be great to have a keynote about ethics in data science.
